net.hudup.server

Class PowerServerImpl

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.hudup.server.PowerServerImpl
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.rmi.Remote, Gateway, PowerServer, Server
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    DefaultServer

    public abstract class PowerServerImpl
extends java.lang.Object
implements PowerServer, Gateway
    This is abstract class for power sever which is the base of recommendation server.
    Note, the sub-architecture of recommendation server (recommender) is inspired from the architecture of Oracle database management system (Oracle DBMS); especially concepts of listener and share memory layer are borrowed from concepts "Listener" and "System Global Area" of Oracle DBMS, respectively, available at https://docs.oracle.com/database/122/index.htm.
    Version:
    10.0
    Author:
    Loc Nguyen
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • addStatusListener

        public boolean addStatusListener(ServerStatusListener listener)
                          throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Description copied from interface: Server
        Server has six statuses as follows:
        • "started": Server started. If server has just started right after calling Server.start(), it is in two statuses: "started" and "running".
        • "paused": Server paused. Server are currently in both "started" status and "paused" status.
        • "resumed": Server resumed. Server are currently in three statuses: "started", "resumed", and "running".
        • "stopped": Server stopped and so server is in "stopped" status.
        • "setconfig": Server is in setting its configuration. Sever must stop so that it can set its configuration. So server is now in two statuses: "stopped" and "setconfig".
        • "exit": Server exits and so server does not exist. Status "exit" is unreal.
        Some statuses are overlapped; for example, server is in status "paused" is also in status "started". When server changes its current status by calling methods such as Server.start(), Server.pause(), Server.resume(), Server.stop(), and Server.exit(). Methods such as Server.isStarted(), Server.isPaused(), and Server.isRunning() are used to query current status of server. Every time server change its current status, it notifies an event ServerStatusEvent to listeners that implement ServerStatusListener interface. Such listeners are called server status listeners, which must be registered with server by this method Server.addStatusListener(ServerStatusListener) to receive server status events. A server status event is removed from server by calling Server.removeStatusListener(ServerStatusListener).
        Specified by:
        addStatusListener in interface Server
        Parameters:
        listener - the server status listener that is registered into this server in order to receive server status event represented by ServerStatusEvent class.
        Returns:
        whether add listener successfully
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException - if any error raises.

      • ping

      • removeStatusListener

        public boolean removeStatusListener(ServerStatusListener listener)
                             throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Description copied from interface: Server
        Server has six statuses as follows:
        • "started": Server started. If server has just started right after calling Server.start(), it is in two statuses: "started" and "running".
        • "paused": Server paused. Server are currently in both "started" status and "paused" status.
        • "resumed": Server resumed. Server are currently in three statuses: "started", "resumed", and "running".
        • "stopped": Server stopped and so server is in "stopped" status.
        • "setconfig": Server is in setting its configuration. Sever must stop so that it can set its configuration. So server is now in two statuses: "stopped" and "setconfig".
        • "exit": Server exits and so server does not exist. Status "exit" is unreal.
        Some statuses are overlapped; for example, server is in status "paused" is also in status "started". When server changes its current status by calling methods such as Server.start(), Server.pause(), Server.resume(), Server.stop(), and Server.exit(). Methods such as Server.isStarted(), Server.isPaused(), and Server.isRunning() are used to query current status of server. Every time server change its current status, it notifies an event ServerStatusEvent to listeners that implement ServerStatusListener interface. Such listeners are called server status listeners, which must be registered with server by this method Server.addStatusListener(ServerStatusListener) to receive server status events. A server status event is unregistered from server by calling this method Server.removeStatusListener(ServerStatusListener).
        Specified by:
        removeStatusListener in interface Server
        Parameters:
        listener - the server status listener that is unregistered from server and it no longer received server status event.
        Returns:
        whether add listener successfully
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException - if any error raises.
